items.title: These Democrats Could Hold the Key to Ending the Shutdown
items.summary: As the federal closure slides into a second week, Republicans are working to peel off five more Democratic senators to join them in voting to reopen the government.

items.title: JB Pritzker Has Had it With Democrats Who Won’t Stand Up to Trump
items.summary: The Illinois governor, a potential presidential candidate, is fighting the presence of National Guard troops and the activities of ICE agents in Chicago.

items.title: Trump Fires Black Officials From an Overwhelmingly White Administration
items.summary: Separately, in the administration’s first 200 days, only two of 98 Senate-confirmed appointees to the most senior jobs in government were Black.

items.title: Before Trump Ordered In Troops, Federal Officers Called Portland Protests ‘Low Energy’
items.summary: Oregon officials say the atmosphere outside an ICE building that has drawn daily demonstrations since June has grown worse since the president’s threats.

items.title: The Harvard ‘Die-in’ That Set Off a Debate Over Protest and Punishment
items.summary: An Israeli American student said he was assaulted during a protest. Two years later, Republicans continue to raise the episode in their campaign to force schools to punish the student protesters.

items.title: Tom Homan Was Said to Have Received $50,000 From Agents. He May Not Have to Return It.
items.summary: Public corruption experts said the Justice Department had options for recovering money used in a sting operation. But that may not happen for years.

items.title: Senate again fails to pass stopgap funding bill as government shutdown drags into eighth day – live
items.summary: <p>Senate fails for sixth time to pass a funding bill in 54-45 vote – three Democrats sided with Republicans in attempt to reach 60-vote threshold</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/08/government-shutdown-airports-delays">US airport staffing shortages set to cause more delays amid shutdown</a></p></li><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/08/government-shutdown-childcare-bill-democrats">Democrat bill aims to help federal workers cover childcare costs</a></p></li></ul><p><strong>A <a href="https://www.nationalreview.com/news/dem-ag-nominee-jay-jones-fantasized-about-shooting-former-virginia-gop-speaker-he-receives-both-bullets/">series of “violent” texts</a> sent by a Democrat seeking to become Virginia’s attorney general has shaken up the state’s governor’s race, with Republican candidate Winsome Earle-Sears seizing on the controversy to try to reverse her opponent’s double-digit polling lead.</strong></p><p>Earle-Sears has released<a href="https://x.com/winwithwinsome/status/1974832866388566097?s=46&amp;t=uQxq3EX7p3bygcqVfUnstg"> new campaign advertisements</a> condemning Democratic former congresswoman Abigail Spanberger, her opponenent in the governor’s race, for continuing to support Jay Jones, whose private texts three years ago speculated about a senior state Republican getting “two bullets to the head” and “breeding little fascists”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/oct/08/donald-trump-james-comey-justice-department-national-guard-chicago-antifa-government-shutdown-us-politics-live-news-updates">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: Military should only be used for external threats, more than half of Americans say
items.summary: <p>Survey finds 58% backing restricting armed forces to external threats amid Trump deployments to US cities</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/oct/08/donald-trump-james-comey-justice-department-national-guard-chicago-antifa-government-shutdown-us-politics-live-news-updates">US politics – live updates</a></p></li></ul><p>More than half of Americans believe that the US government should only deploy armed troops in the event of external threats, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/most-americans-dont-want-troops-deployed-without-an-external-threat-reutersipsos-2025-10-08/">according to</a> a new survey.</p><p>The Reuters/Ipsos survey released on Wednesday found that 58% of Americans believe that the president should only send in armed forces to areas with external threats. Meanwhile, 25% said that they believed the US military could be used for other purposes and 18% said that they were not sure.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/08/military-external-threats-survey-trump">Continue reading...</a>
